ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really enjoyed this class. I gained a much broader understanding of Russian literature, especially in the 1940s/1950s during Stalin.
My skills in reading and knowledge of grammar and vocabulary improved
Continuation of Russian grammar and vocabulary with a focus on literature and film. Oral comprehension and expression. Early soviet history

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: You read very interesting Soviet literature and watch very provocative Soviet/post-Soviet film; however, the class always runs overtime. The session definitely should have been longer!!

I liked how we read excerpts of Russian literature for class - I think it's really interesting to read sources in the original language. However, I felt that the amount of homework assigned was a little inconsistent and often a little too much for the one day between classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Because of the nature of this class, there are many different language levels which can make it hard to tailor the class to everyone's individual needs. There is a good combination of grammar/vocabulary, reading, and speaking practice. The class is very much discussion-based, so be prepared to talk about the readings or practice vocabulary and grammar.

I would definitely recommend this class as a continuation of fourth-year Russian. If you enjoyed and learned from the first semester of this course you will continue to do so in this class. Take especially for the focus on literature and film, and early soviet history.
